events.name: Humla Workshop - Exploit Research - DEP Bypass using Return Oriented Programming
events.description:
We are pleased to inform Humla Hands-On workshop on DEP Bypass using ROP by Mohammed A. Imran @secfigo Please note, this event is a FREE hands-on workshop, we can accommodate only few selected participants. If you get selected, you will receive email from humla champion by 20th August 2016. *** We are looking for more speakers to contribute to this series. Please get in touch if you are interested.  Selection Criteria: Selection (15-20 persons only) will be based on the following two criteria: 1. Contribution to the community. Speakers, humla, bachav champions, core team, volunteers  and venue hosts will get priority to the workshop.  2. Passion towards Information security + the attendance in previous meet ups.   If you are new to the community, selection will be based on the answers to the survey questions asked during the registration process. Please answer these questions carefully.  Agenda:  As part of the Exploit Research Series, we will cover the following topics. 1.  What is DEP and how it makes systems harder to exploit ?  2.  What is ROP and how it helps to bypass DEP 3.  Creating and Modifying ROP Gadgets 


Pre-requisites: Intermediate level of expertise for Assembly Language and should be comfortable working with command line.   Don’t know assembly? Watch these videos - https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL96AB65DFCE02EE3E  Who should attend ? :  Anyone who is interested in low level exploitation, reverse engineering and malware analysis. 


What should I bring with me? : Hardware: Laptop which can run two VMs simultaneously with at least 4 GB RAM and minimum 30 GB hard disk free space. Software:   1. VMware Player Installed with Windows 7 and Kali VM (32 bit). 2. Immunity debugger (free version) installed on the windows 7 VM. You also need to install python for immunity. 3. More instructions will be sent via email.  4. Notepad++  


Null humla champion: Mohammed A Imran aka secfigo is senior software security engineer at Autodesk and specializes in vulnerability assessment, penetration testing and static code analysis. He loves to build infosec communities, share his knowledge with the community  and has organized around 60+ security events for the best null chapter, null hyderabad in India. He now leads null Singapore chapter. When not at work, he likes to practice his design skills and fiddle with development frameworks.  Please reach out to humla champion, if you have any questions regarding the event.
events.group_name: Null Singapore - The Open Security Community

events.name: Discussion and Open space for Emerging Big data and Analytics Technologies
events.description: Agenda : 7:00 PM : Networking and Discussion 7:30 PM : Discussion on Emerging OLTP Databases on top of Hadoop and its future 8:00 PM : Breakout session 9:00 PM : END and BYE BYE
events.location: AXA TOWER, 8 Shenton Way #04-02, AXA TOWER, Singapore 068811

events.name: Emacs Meetup #1
events.description:
A warm welcome to the first Emacs meetup in Singapore! We'll have two talks this meetup: 1. Using Emacs for GTDJethro Kuan GTD is a productivity tool. The basics of GTD will be explained, and an implementation of GTD will be presented. Expect to learn some basic Elisp! 


2. Select your own talk! - Jason Milkins Jason has too many things he would like to share, and was hoping you guys help him choose: • Pcase/Pattern Matching and Destructuring convenience in EmacsLisp • Keyboard productivity hacks for Emacs - with Hydra and more • Projectile, Ido and co • Smerge mode or don't fear the rebase • Kurecolor - interactive color editing 


The venue for this meetup is kindly sponsored by Pivotal Labs Singapore. NOTE: No food/refreshments are provided, so attendees are encouraged to bring your own snacks.
